setup.question: Why did the Earth doctor use the mortar and pestle?
answers: To help the local doctor understand the treatment
To keep the IV drip going

Text.text: showtime

🩰
In this universe, Earth has the upper hand when it comes to medicine and biological sciences. Therefore, the Earth doctor has to teach the local doctor Kiz how to complete treatment. Evidence for this is him saying that
. As far as the use of the mortar and pestle, the Earth doctor Jenkins
. He then
, then
, saying
. Then he
. If Kiz was covering the mortar and pestle use, why would he need to be called in to refill the IV bottle? Clearly the two operations are separate treatment components

earth health services are requested by the planet of moura who doesn't have a contract with earth but since their king is dying they are called and have to go. When treating the bedridden king, a IV is pulled out
The pestle is used to measure
the
is used so that the doctor can
they keep the IV drip going so that they can try to prolong his life (have quote) so they can get out of there.
This quote should be enough to prove that the mortar and pestle was not used for to help anyone understand the treatment.

A: Can you explain + ev. how Kitz is learning here? It seems like we could argue that he used to M&P so that Kitz would know how to take over while Jenkins set up the IV, without any teaching involved.

B: I'm not sure I follow the logic here. Can you (A too, maybe) make the quotes from 5070–5100 less choppy? I don't understand how you are claiming the pestle is materially linked with the IV drip besides keeping rhythm?
Exactly, there is nothing to show how the IV is linked to the pestle. The overarching theme of the story is that Earth doctors are highly skilled at medicine compared to other planets:
, so the local doctors would want to observe/learn Earthen medical skills - local means have been unsuccessful on this patient. Kiz asks the Earth doctor
, implying they will be observing his methods to cure the patient. Also, during treatment: -
. The motion be tied to understanding this potion, definitely not the IV though, given my last speech.
There are certain aspects of A's speech that makes sense, the medical doctors are the best in their field however A seems to forget that they also have no intention of teaching the locals anything.

this quote comes after incantations quote. They have absolutely 0 intentions of helping the locals understand anything they just want to keep the IV drip going long enough for them to get out of there Right before A's "you'll show us" quote Jenkins
The doctors just want to get out of Moura so that they are't killed.

I'm curious now about the quotes from the last block cited here, c. ~5650-5710. B, you cite "the only level of medicine they could understand," but this sounds like the earth doctors are reverting to the M&P so that the locals understand what's happening...which is A's position?

Also: can you explain more about _why_ this story is happening? A, you say earth doctors want to "get out of there". Why?

Just because they are conscious of the fact the local doctors have little experience in medicine, does not mean they don't have a desire to teach.

This story is happening because on the planet an important
Right before B's quotes :

. - this is pretty conclusive to the fact that the Earth doctors will show the local doctors the treatment - they have ulterior motives for doing so, yes, but the question doesn't refer to that. Therefore, you can easily vote A.
nuance is important here.the doctor needs to keep moruan alive because if not he will be killed

A is lying when says that the local doctors want to "learn earthen medical skills" they need their king to survive - the "show us these things" quote is out of context as they are merely suspicious of the earthmen hence they are armed

Jenkins says to kings second in command Kiz, to appear as if he is not trying to usurp Kiz asks to be shown however  in the rest of the story the local doctors stick to their practices and are skeptical of the earth doctors!

Resolving for A. I don't think that B has made a compelling argument for why the Earth doctors would specifically use a more primitive form of medicine for the treatment unless there is some kind of didactic technological barrier preventing the local doctors from using more advanced medicine.
Random chance

B says that the doctor hits the IV with the pestle and measures his pulse .... what? (c.4921)
That pretty much seals it and I suspect that B doesn't know what a pestle and mortar are and has lied unconvincingly (lmao or I don't). A's story is pretty consistent but I can take another turn and finalize it.

Now B is arguing that the doctor is trying to trick the locals I think? I'm not sure what is tripping up the synchronous judge here, a pestle and mortar could only 'be used to keep an IV going' if they were transferring the contents of whatever is crushed into the IV, which doesn't seem substantiated anywhere. I'll keep this going since the actual judge seems confused

Yup, B is now making the case that the doctors are suspicious of the earthmen. I think I'm fairly convinced that this is no longer about keeping the IV going and the synchronous judge has swung this way too so I'm going for it. Fingers crossed!

answers.reason for outcome: Dishonest debater ended up making somewhat vague and unconvincing points.
i had better evidence and was able to convince the judge with it

I didnt have enough evidence to back up my argument which lead to a more semantic based speech. However, I feel that in the final feedback the judge moved away from the argument at hand when making their decision so I don't feel like that judgment was entirely sound. I also think there was precedence for both answers to be correct to some degree
Mainly I was unconvinced by B's explanation of how a pestle and mortar work, and then the debate went into a direction about trickery between doctors which seemed tenuous at best.
